thread.title: Star Wars: The force awakens with a shudder as Star Wars trailer shakes the internet
thread.title_full: Star Wars: The force awakens with a shudder as Star Wars trailer shakes the internet

author: Michael Idato
title: Star Wars: The force awakens with a shudder as Star Wars trailer shakes the internet
text:
Click to play video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Trailer - Star Wars: The Force Awakens (trailer 3) Coming to Australian cinemas December 17.
PT2M4S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44tz7 620 349 October 20, 2015 Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings The Force Awakens: scene by scene Star Wars trailer gets three of its own trailers Red hot ticket sales in Australia Thanks to a succession of sneak peeks and teaser trailers you could be forgiven for thinking you've already seen most of the new Star Wars film The Force Awakens . But as the old adage goes, the best is yet to come.
The film's official trailer was released today, aired on US television during a football game and then distributed online via YouTube and the US studio Disney's social media channels.
Star Wars has released its new look. 
Though it is the third actual trailer released for the film, it is the first official trailer; the two earlier trailers, released last November and in April this year, were considered "teasers", though the distinction is sometimes not easy to make.
Advertisement Anticipation around the release of the official trailer was so big it had three mini-trailers of its own .
And its release was tied to the release of the film's official poster . 
The sequential release of trailers is an old Hollywood tradition, though modern studios play a more calculated game in terms of timing and positioning. Disney's most recent mega-blockbuster, Avengers: Age of Ultron , was managed in a similar fashion, with early teasers pitched at franchise fans and then an official trailer premiered during Monday Night Football.
While the football audience is a large one, and, notably, a mainstream one, it is also aired on ESPN, a Disney-owned sports network. By giving ESPN the first look at the trailer the studio is, in effect, looking after its own.
The new film has been effectively in play since the US studio Disney acquired George Lucas's production company Lucasfilm in 2012, though the name The Force Awakens was not announced until some time later.
As part of that deal, Disney acquired the Star Wars franchise, and has already demonstrated formidable plans for it, announcing a new trilogy, three more standalone films and Star Wars-focused expansions to its billion-dollar theme parks business.
The first teaser trailer was released almost a year ago - November 28, 2014. That 88-second teaser - "There has been an awakening, have you felt it?" it asked - introduced Finn (John Boyega), BB8, the new-look stormtroopers, Daisy Ridley, Poe Dameron and the cross-bladed lightsaber-wielding Kylo Ren.
A second two-minute teaser trailer was released on April 16, 2015, at the Star Wars Celebration convention in Los Angeles. It was pitched at the Star Wars heartland, the fans who had loved the franchise since its 1977 debut, and featured glimpses of crashed Star Destroyers, Darth Vader's burned breath mask (complete with a hind of his breath in the soundtrack) and narration from Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill).
It also featured the first proper confirmation that the "original trilogy" cast were on board - literally - with a clip featuring Harrison Ford (as Han Solo) and his loyal co-pilot Chewbacca (Peter Mayhew) walking onto the Millennium Falcon.
"Chewie we're home," Solo said. And then fans were treated to an almost four-minute-long behind-the-scenes video at the annual Comic-Con convention in San Diego.
That package featured production artwork, filming miniatures, incomplete action sequences and an extensive look behind the scene, including an interview with Mark Hamill, clips of Peter Mayhew (Chewbacca) and Anthony Daniels (C3P0) on set and the partially-constructed full-size props of the X-Wing fighter and the Millennium Falcon props.
"My whole life has led to this moment," actor Simon Pegg said. It was a sentiment echoed by all the cast and, by extension, the Star Wars fans watching. "It's being done with such love and such enthusiasm from everybody," Oscar Isaac said.
But Disney is teasing no longer; the trailer released today is the film's first official trailer. And in it fans were treated to the most detailed glimpse into the film's narrative so far.
Star Wars: The Force Awakens opens in Australia on December 17.
